> A communication problem occurs when we ask why things like "systems of processes," "organism," "I," etc., are not us. Fundamentally they are labels that point to concepts that we store in our brain, which do not actually capture the sensory experience in any way.

Pretty much. "Realization" is largely about distinguishing things that are ***about*** you vs things that are directly you. Essentially, getting past all the symbols/concepts/thoughts and instead opting for the direct experience. 

In this, the idea of time gets mentioned a lot just because we use it so much to refer to ourselves indirectly. 

For example, you can think **about** tomorrow. And if you try to go to the direct experience of tomorrow, you realize, oh wait, there isn't. Was a thought/symbol/concept all along.

Being short is a fact, so it doesn't take time
Being tall is a fact, so it doesn't take time
Why does it seem like it takes time when you compare the two?

Because you think itsyou. You think youre short in the past because of your memories, but you also think youre tall because of what you presently see. Youve created a definition about yourself that you can relate to, which is height. I am tall/short. u should inquire with it as if you're both "in the same boat" and on a level playing field (just exploring experience).  ask for more details about what it says if it seems nonsensical or confusing, don't assume you have to take it at face value or that it is 100% correct, in the exact same way you would with urself in your own inquiry. look at it like there are two inquirers instead of one.

u can clarify the inquiry at any point just by asking clarifying questions, like "what do you mean im the one who is aware" or "what do you mean thought can't touch non-duality" and it will immediately tell you its thought process on why it said that, and then from there you can constructively scrutinize the inquiry and come to a resolution

practically though, my best inquiries have been where i just find a non-dual quote or text to start it off with, and i say something like "what can you interpret and summarize from this text? what are the implications?" You want it to be open-ended and not rigid so that it's free to practice its logic

> Previously I genuinely did not understand how to possibly get under it

There's nothing to really "get under", that's the "realization". Problems and solutions are ***ideals*** about something which is already a ***fact***. When you identify with something which isn't a fact (non-existence), it creates aversive and resistant emotions.

The "reaction", which is resistance or separation from what is, is itself the emotion. No reaction means no emotion. It's what you're mentally adding to what is already the case which creates effort/resistance/emotion. What is already the case takes no effort because it's already the case. 

Basically, you want to be a "perfect conduit" for emotions. Let it pass through you like a superconductor. Acknowledge and express the idea/belief/interpretation being felt (as an emotion), like "i hate this thing". Allow the idea to be experienced no matter how it feels, and at the moment of allowing it you will find that the emotion vanishes because at that moment there is no idealizing of something other than the experience, which is what creates and perpetuates the emotion in the first place. 

When you try to move away from the interpretation which is felt as an emotion, it prevents the emotion from "passing through" and causes the emotion to loop via some circular self-fulfilling logic. Like, for example, "maybe in the future I'll be happy".

> And are you aware of all sensations before any action takes place?

Everyone is aware. The thought "not aware" wouldn't actually be something you're aware of, by its own definition. Anything that "is not", is separate from what is, so it isn't.

> But then, why do I want to solve the sounds if being ignorant of them (seemingly) results in peace?

You can't be ignorant of a belief. The belief is ignorance. Just like you can't be ignorant of Santa. If you knew about Santa, that would be ignorance.

Peace isn't the result of an action, it's the cessation of action or effort, or returning back to what is already the case and what has always been the case.

Peace isn't about defeating Santa and saving everyone. It's simply, not Santa. Santa is not reality. Reality is therein, peace. Reality requires no effort in being itself, which is not Santa, because it is already itself. 

Resistance is therefore identifying with "not-reality" (me and Santa), and thus perpetuating it through thought-loops.

> Would that relationship cause the emotion

"Relationships cause emotions" is just another relationship, between relationships and emotion. You've made a recursion. The recursion, or, the belief, causes emotions to loop or perpetuate, because it's circular logic and there is no separation. 

The attempt at "solving" is the recursive "moving away" or "obscuring" of the initial belief or emotion. Like someone trying to solve how they can get off of Santa's naughty list, all the while overlooking that there isn't a Santa in the first place. The naughty list appears as a solution for dealing with Santa, but it actually just allows the idea of Santa to perpetuate even longer.

> What would you recommend for guided meditation? 

Youtube had some good ones IIRC, you can just do a general search. Doesn't have to be long if you don't want it to, 10-20 mins. Something that focuses on what is already present in your awareness, like the breath or bodily sensations. 

IME, in the morning, mid-day, or at night, is good. Whenever you feel like "resetting". It's kind of like taking a shower, but like, a mental shower.

only conceptually speaking, but not actually/experientially. as in, there's no before and after self-realization, in the same way there's no "before and after gravity". there's only whether you currently recognize if gravity is there or not, or whether you currently buy into the appearing thought/belief of a separate self. in my opinion, no. self-inquiry is just about asking a question about yourself, hence, "self-inquiry". you are inquiring about the self. the answer/response to the question brings you into contact with belief/knowledge about yourself so that it can be examined and dispelled.

you can imagine someone who holds a physical mirror, and they hold it up to themselves whenever someone asks them who they are so they can point at the mirror and say "thats me". this is pretty much exactly what happens in self-inquiry, by asking the question (about yourself), you bring up the belief/knowledge you currently recognize yourself in. analogously, you arent in a mirror, and you arent in a thought.

somewhat tangential, but the disillusionment that comes from a practice like meditation (simply being still physically and mentally, so that your only task becomes to observe and abide as awareness), is so that you stop "holding up the mirror" for long enough to realize "oh, i havent felt worry in an hour, thats weird, i always thought of myself as someone who is always worried" which spirals into the realization "damn the person thats worried isn't actually here at all".
